questions.text: The radiological investigation of choice for avascular necrosis of bone is ________
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for avascular necrosis of bone is MRI as initially, bone infarction occurs in the marrow.

Avascular necrosis or osteonecrosis is a painful bone condition resulting from diminished blood supply mainly due to trauma or non-traumatic etiologies. 

The typical features are pain with movements in or near the joint, click in the joint, joint stiffness, limping gait, and deformity. Restriction of actions is also a feature of this condition.

The radiograph shows reactive new bone formation, increased radiolucency in the subchondral bone, and a distorted articular surface. MRI has high sensitivity and specificity in diagnosis.

Management in the early stages can involve osteotomy while in late stages pain control, splinting, arthrodesis and total or partial replacement are preferred.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic obese male patient presented to the emergency department with severe pain abdomen radiating to the back. Blood investigations revealed increased serum amylase and lipase levels. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of the patient is suggestive of acute pancreatitis. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the imaging investigation of choice. 

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gallstone-induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post-endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. USG cannot help establish the diagnosis of pancreatitis. Plain erect chest x-ray and abdominal radiographs are not diagnostic of acute pancreatitis and can only be used to rule out certain differentials. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the imaging investigation of choice, but may not always be needed. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Acute Pancreatitis

Symptoms:

  • Acute onset of epigastric pain, which is severe, constant, and refractory to usual doses of analgesics.
  • Typically radiates to back
  • Relieved in the sitting forward position
  • Nausea, repeated vomiting, retching, and hiccups

Signs:

  • Hypotension, tachycardia, and tachypnea
  • Grey Turner sign (A): Bluish discoloration of the flanks
  • Cullen’s sign (B): Bluish discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Fox sign: Discolouration below the inguinal ligament
  • Pleural effusion (left > right): Dullness on percussion, decreased breath sounds

Related Pearl: Causes of Acute Pancreatitis

Common causes

  • Gallstones - most common
  • Alcohol
  • Post-ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography)
  • Blunt trauma, abdomen
  • Post-operative (cardiothoracic, upper gastrointestinal, biliary)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Sphincter of Oddi dysfunction

Uncommon causes

  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Deficiency of apolipoprotein CII
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Periampullary diverticulum
  • Vasculitis
  • Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP)
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Ischemic–hypoperfusion states
  • Hereditary pancreatitis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Renal failure

Drugs

  • L-Asparaginase
  • Steroids
  • Sulfonamides
  • Tetracycline
  • Valproate
  • Azathioprine
  • Anti-retroviral drugs
  • Estrogens
  • Thiazide diuretics

Rare causes

  • Autoimmune
  • Infections (mumps, coxsackie B, cytomegalovirus, parasite)
  • Malnutrition
  • Scorpion bite

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

The X-ray given below shows sentinel loop sign (marked as '1') and colon cut-off sign (marked as '2') in a patient with acute pancreatitis:

 

Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: A pediatrician suspects vesicoureteric reflux in a girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. What is the investigation of choice to confirm this condition?
questions.solution:
Voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux.

Recurrent febrile urinary tract infections in a child should raise the suspicion of an anatomical defect like vesicoureteric reflux as the cause. Compared to other investigations, a VCUG provides more anatomic information. It can demonstrate:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux
  • Duplex collecting system
  • Ectopic ureter
  • Paraureteral (bladder) diverticulum
  • Bladder outlet obstruction
  • Signs of voiding dysfunction, such as a spinning top urethra

questions.text: A 68-year-old hypertensive male patient presented with a sudden onset tearing type of chest pain, prompting suspicion of aortic dissection. On examination, the patient was hemodynamically unstable. What is the diagnostic modality of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The diagnostic modality of choice in a hemodynamically unstable patient with suspected acute aortic dissection is transesophageal echocardiography.

Transesophageal echocardiography can be done at the bedside in patients who are too unstable for transportation; it can give information about flow in the true and false lumen and shows very high sensitivity for confirmation of the aortic dissection. Currently, a CT scan is the initial best investigation for the diagnosis of aortic dissection in the hemodynamically stable patient. Additionally, it tells about the extent of the dissection.

Magnetic resonance imaging has perfect sensitivity and specificity making it one of the most accurate tools for the diagnosis of an aortic dissection. On an MRI the contrast between the lumen and aortic wall makes the detection of intimal flap easy. Multidetector computerized tomography (MDCT) provides very high image quality with much shorter acquisition times.

Aortic dissection occurs when a defect or flap occurs in the intima of the aorta.

Predisposing factors for aortic dissection are:

  • Age
  • Hypertension
  • Marfan syndrome
  • Pregnancy
  • Other connective tissue disorders, for example, Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • Turner or Noonan syndromes
  • Aortic cannulation site (iatrogenic)

Clinical features:

  • The most typical presentation of aortic dissection is a tearing interscapular pain.
  • The tracheal tug sign, also known as Oliver’s sign, is seen in the arch of the aorta aneurysm.
  • It is elicited by gently grasping the cricoid cartilage and applying upward pressure while the patient stands with their chin extended upward. Due to the anatomical position of the arch, which overrides the left main bronchus, a tug on the trachea is felt if an aneurysm is present. Therefore, it is also called the tracheal tug sign.

The dissection can extend distally down the aorta to involve the:

  • Renal arteries (renal pain and renal failure)
  • Mesenteric arteries (abdominal pain and bowel ischemia)
  • Spinal arteries (paraplegia)
  • Iliac arteries (leg pain, pallor, loss or reduced pulses, and limb ischemia).

The dissection may track proximally to involve the:

  • Head and neck vessels (symptoms and signs of a stroke or transient ischaemic attack)
  • Coronary vessels (MI)
  • Aortic root (aortic regurgitation)

The dissection may also result in aortic wall rupture into the pericardium (cardiac tamponade) or mediastinum (left haemothorax).

Below is the CT image showing the double lumen of the aorta is suggestive of aortic dissection.

Management:

The initial management of patients diagnosed with aortic dissection is beta-blocker medication to control hypertension, along with pain management. The preferred beta-blocker drug is esmolol. These reduce cardiac contractility and blood pressure.

Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated in acute dissection because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and worsen the dissection. CCBs like verapamil and diltiazem may be used IV if nitroprusside or beta-blockers cannot be employed.

Once hypertension is controlled, definitive surgical repair of aortic dissection is done.

Treatment options:

  • Stanford type A (DeBakey types I and II) requires surgical intervention once the patient's blood pressure is stabilized.
  • Stanford type B (DeBakey type III) is best managed by antihypertensive drugs. Surgical intervention is indicated in complicated cases if the pain increases (signalling impending rupture) or when there is evidence of malperfusion of organs or neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fever and colicky right upper quadrant pain and tenderness in the same area. Levels of bilirubin, transaminases, and alkaline phosphatase are mildly elevated. What is the most suitable investigation for the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
The initial investigation of choice in this patient with suspected cholecystitis is Ultrasonography (USG).

Acute cholecystitis is usually due to mechanical obstruction of the cystic duct or gallbladder neck by a gall- stone. It presents as fever, nausea, vomiting, and pain in the right hypochondrium with referred pain to the back. On examination, Murphy's sign—pain caused by inspiration while applying pressure to the right upper abdomen, causing the patient to stop breathing—is seen.

Ultrasonography (USG) is the initial investigation of choice. USG showing gallstones, pericholecystic fluid, and gallbladder wall thickening is diagnostic. CT is less sensitive(Option C) than ultrasound for the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis, though it usually shows similar findings to USG.

In cases where USG is normal, a HIDA scan (Option D) is done to confirm the diagnosis. Failure to visualize the gallbladder 2 hours after injection demonstrates obstruction of the cystic duct, which definitively diagnoses acute cholecystitis. Filling of the gallbladder during a HIDA scan essentially eliminates the diagnosis of cholecystitis.

Treatment including cholecystectomy done within 72 hours has better outcomes that interval surgery

The following image depicts the radioisotope scan in which the gallbladder and biliary tree are visualized:

 

Other options:

Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) involves the use of a side-viewing duodenoscope, which is passed through the pylorus and into the second part of the duodenum to visualize the papilla. It is both a diagnostic and curative procedure in the management of biliary tree pathologies.

Magnetic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is involved in the non-invasive imaging of the biliary tree.

 

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Gall Bladder

  • Gallbladder Ultrasound: Investigation of choice for detection of gall stones
  • Abdominal X-ray: Useful in 
    • Calcified gall stones
    • Emphysematous cholecystitis
    • Porcelain gallbladder
    • Limey bile
    • Gallstone ileus
  • Radioisotope scans (HIDA/DIDA/DISIDA)
    • Indicated for confirmation of suspected acute cholecystitis
    • Useful in diagnosis of acalculous cholecystopathy

Abbreviations:

  • HIDA: Hepatobiliary IminoDiacetic Acid scan
  • DIDA/DISDA: Di-isopropyl IminoDiacetic Acid - Dynamic Tc99m DIDA Cholescintigraphy

questions.text: A 50-year-old smoker presented with miosis, ptosis of the right eye, and anhidrosis of the right side of the face. He also has occasional chest pain along with fever and weight loss for the past month. A pancoast tumour is suspected. Which of the following is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor) and the investigation of choice is MRI.

Investigations in Pancoast tumor:

  • MRI (MRI > CT) is the investigation of choice for superior sulcus tumor/ Pancoast tumor as the associated soft tissue infiltration, the extent of which can be best visualized using an MRI.
  • FDG-PET scan shows high uptake by the tumor cells. FDG is taken up by all metabolizing cells but more avidly by cancer cells.
  • Bronchoscopy can be done in endobronchial tumors to obtain a tissue diagnosis.

Pancoast syndrome/ superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots, stellate ganglion, and the chest wall.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs.

Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

The below images show chest x-ray, FDG-PET images, and management of the Pancoast tumor.

 

Related Pearl: Investigation of Choice in Respiratory Diseases

Disease Investigation of choice
Interstitial lung disease HRCT
Bronchiectasis HRCT
Pulmonary embolism CT Pulmonary Angiography > Ventilation-Perfusion Scan
Calcification CT
Solitary pulmonary nodule CT > PET
Lung Malignancy CT scan
Superior sulcus tumor MRI scan > CT scan

questions.text:
A 36-year-old man presents with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum. His blood work showed raised LDH and AFP. Which of the following is the imaging modality of choice?

LDH - Lactate dehydrogenase.

AFP - α-fetoprotein.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a middle-aged man presenting with a painless testicular mass with a sense of heaviness in the scrotum suggests the diagnosis of a testicular tumour. Blood work showed raised LDH and AFP, which are tumour markers for non-seminomatous germ cell tumours (NSGCTs). The imaging modality of choice is ultrasonography.

Testicular tumours are uncommon male malignancies. Seminomas generally occur in the 4th decade of life, while NSGCTs are common in the 3rd decade of life. Spermatocytic seminomas occur commonly in men older than 50 years.

Clinical features of testicular tumours are:

  • Occurrence in the specific age group.
  • Painless testicular mass is the usual symptom
  • Sense of scrotal heaviness
  • Abdominal or lumbar mass due to metastasis
  • Chest pain, dyspnea, and haemoptysis due to lung metastasis
  • Prepubertal interstitial cell tumours produce androgens, causing precocious puberty
  • Postpubertal interstitial cell tumours produce feminising hormones, leading to gynecomastia, erectile dysfunction, loss of libido and azoospermia.

The initial diagnostic investigation of choice is ultrasonography (USG). USG of the affected as well as the unaffected testis is done and is mandatory. Tumour markers aid in the diagnosis. Chest X-ray is done to detect 'cannonball' metastasis in the lungs.

Other options:

Option A - Contrast-Enhanced Computed Tomography (CECT) is done to assess the thoracic, abdominal and pelvic areas for metastasis. Although it is essential in staging and monitoring response to therapy, it is not the imaging modality of choice.

Option C: Trans-scrotal biopsy has no role in the diagnosis of testicular tumours.

Option D: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) may be used as an adjunct if ultrasound findings are equivocal or if the location of the mass is uncertain.

 Note:

 Alpha-fetoprotein AFP: Raised in

  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Yolk sac tumor
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Mixed germ cell tumor

AFP is never raised in pure seminomas or pure choriocarcinoma

Human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG): Only the β subunit is measured by the most commonly available serum assays. Can be raised in

  • Choriocarcinoma
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Teratocarcinoma
  • Seminoma (only in about 15% Seminomas)
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

questions.text: A neonate is brought on the 5th day of life with abdominal distension. The mother informs that the child has not passed meconium yet. Distal bowel obstruction is suspected. What is the diagnostic test of choice?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation (abdominal distension and failure to pass meconium) is suggestive of Hirschsprung’s disease. Contrast enema is used as the initial investigation when Hirschsprung’s disease is suspected and is the diagnostic test of choice. Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation.

Hirschsprung disease or congenital aganglionic colon is characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus and submucosal (Meissner) plexus of the distal intestinal segment. This is because of the premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum.

It causes a muscular spasm of the distal intestinal segment, resulting in functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation (megacolon). The area between the dilated and contracted segments is referred to as the transition zone.

Hirschsprung disease is classified into -

  • Short-segment - limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment - proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

Note: while the gold standard investigation for Hirschsprung’s disease is rectal suction biopsy, an imaging study will first be required to figure out the location from where the sample needs to be taken.

The image below shows dilated ganglionic and contracted aganglionic segments in Hirschsprung's disease,

It is more common in males. Most infants present with abdominal distension and bilious vomiting with failure to pass meconium within the first 24 hours of life. Enterocolitis is a potentially fatal complication.

It may be familial or associated with Down syndrome. The following gene mutations can be seen,

  • Mutations in chromosome 10 (loss-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET) or chromosome 13
  • glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) mutations

GDNF promotes the survival, proliferation, and migration of neural crest cells in culture. It is expressed in the gut in advance of migrating neural crest cells and is chemoattractive for neural crest cells in culture. 

The investigations for Hirschsprung’s disease include:

Water-soluble contrast enema is the initial investigation. It shows a narrow aganglionic segment, a conical transition zone, and a dilated proximal bowel. It helps in excluding other causes of distal intestinal obstruction, such as colonic atresia, meconium ileus, and meconium plug syndrome. It is both diagnostic and therapeutic for the latter.

A contrast enema image in Hirschsprung's disease is shown below,

Rectal biopsy is the gold standard investigation. It shows the following:

  • Absent ganglia
  • Hypertrophied nerve trunks
  • Positive immunostaining for acetylcholinesterase
  • Calretinin immunostain­ing (superior to acetylcholinesterase staining)

The ideal site to obtain a rectal biopsy in a patient with Hirschsprung's disease is from a point that is at least 2 cm above the dentate line to avoid sampling the normal aganglionated region of the internal sphincter.

Anorectal manometry shows the failure of the relaxation of the internal anal sphincter. It can be performed in older children, but it is relatively inaccurate and rarely used.

The management of Hirschsprung’s disease is as follows:

Surgery is the definitive treatment. A multi-stage approach may be adopted. A colostomy is done in the newborn period, followed by a definitive pull-through operation when the child is over 10 kgs.

Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:

  • Swenson
  • Duhamel
  • Soave

questions.text: A 4-week old infant presented to the emergency department with projectile, nonbilious vomiting after feeding. On examination, a firm ovoid abdominal mass with hyperperistalsis is present. What is the Investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. Ultrasound examination is the Investigation of choice for this condition. Ultrasound examination confirms the diagnosis of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) in the majority of cases. Cervix sign and Nipple sign are signs of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis in USG.

 CHPS typically presents with the following:

  • Non-bilious vomiting, which is progressive, projectile, occurring immediately after a feed, usually presents after the 3rd week of age. 
  •  Physical examination reveals a firm, ovoid, 1 to 2 cm abdominal mass, and abnormal left to right hyperperistalsis is seen.
  • As the vomiting continues, a progressive loss of fluid, hydrogen ions, chloride ions, and potassium leads to hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

Pathogenesis: Hyperplasia of the pyloric muscularis propria, which obstructs the gastric outflow tract.

Treatment: Surgical splitting of the muscularis (Ramstedt pyloromyotomy) is curative.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, and headache for the past 5 days. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the life cycle shown in the image is suggestive of leptospirosis (Weil's disease). A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by leptospira. Humans are infected when the leptospires in water contaminated by the urine of carrier animals enter the body through cuts or abrasions on the skin or through the intact mucosa of the mouth, nose, or conjunctiva.

Clinical features include fever, jaundice, vomiting, headache, and intense injection of the eyes. Some may present as aseptic meningitis or with hepatorenal damage (Weil's disease).

Diagnosis includes:

  • Microscopy -
    • Examination of blood - Leptospires may be demonstrated under the dark field microscope or by immunofluorescence. The organism disappears from blood after 1 week.
    • Examination of urine: Leptospires appear in the urine in the second week of the disease. Centrifuged deposit of the urine may be examined under dark ground illumination.
  • Culture - With semisynthetic media like EMJH (Ellinghausen, McCullough, Johnson, Harris) or Korthof's, Stuart's, and Fletcher's media.
  • Serotype-specific tests: 
    • Microscopic agglutination test (more specific)
    • Macroscopic agglutination test  
    • A rapid diagnostic test to detect leptospira-specific IgM antibody in human sera.

The treatment of choice is IV penicillin or IV ceftriaxone. Doxycycline 200 mg orally given once a week is effective in prophylaxis.

Option A: Widal test is used to screen for typhoid fever.

Option C: Weil-Felix reaction is used to diagnose rickettsial fevers  

Option D: Paul-Bunnell test is the investigation of choice for infectious mononucleosis.

questions.text: A term neonate is being evaluated for altered level of consciousness. There are also decreased spontaneous movements and abnormal respiration on examination prompting the suspicion for Intraventricular hemorrhage. Which of the following is the investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
Cranial Ultrasonography is the preferred modality for diagnosis of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) because of the high sensitivity, ease of access and lack of radiation exposure. 

The most important risk factor for intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is prematurity with high incidence in very low birth weight (VLBW) infants weighing <1500 g at birth. The risk of GMH-IVH increases with decreasing gestational age and birth weight. Some other risk factors that increase its incidence include respiratory distress, mechanical ventilation, cardiopulmonary resuscitation and hypotension.

The origin of bleeding is the small blood vessels in the germinal matrix, located between the caudate nucleus and the thalamus at the level of the foramen of Monro. In preterm infants, a weak structural support system makes the germinal matrix vulnerable to hemorrhage and injury particularly when there is hemodynamic instability.

 Most cases present on the first day of life and the majority in the first few days of life. The most common presentation is a stuttering course with altered levels of consciousness, respiratory cycle alterations, hypotonia, decreased spontaneous and elicited movements, and subtle changes in eye position and movement. Catastrophic deterioration occurs in very few patients with seizures, coma and decerebrate posturing progressing over minutes to hours. Some patients may have a clinically silent presentation.

Ultrasound is the preferred modality because of the high sensitivity, ease of access and lack of radiation exposure. Routine ultrasound screening is recommended for infants born at < 28 weeks gestation. CT scan is useful to detect cortical neuronal injury and Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is used to evaluate any hypoxic ischemic brain injury.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presents with red violaceous skin lesion with a palpable mass on his forearm. History reveals that this finding has been present since childhood and has been increasing in size. On examination warmth, bruit and thrill are present. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of arteriovenous malformation (AVM). MRI is the investigation of choice for the evaluation and follow-up of peripheral arteriovenous malformations.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) offers numerous advantages over both CT and radiographs and has become the most important modality to diagnose arteriovenous malformations. MRI techniques including time-of-flight and phase contrast can be used to isolate inflow blood supply to better predict the risk of ischemia following embolization.

MRI also provides well-defined images defining boundaries between the AVM, surrounding fat, and neurovascular bundles, which is necessary for the planning of surgical or embolic interventions.

On examination, AVM appears as a red/violaceous lesion with a palpable mass under it. Local warmth, bruit, and thrill are present.

Treatment is initiated when signs and symptoms of ischemia, ulceration, bleeding, or hemodynamic instability are present. Surgical management includes arterial embolization to temporarily occlude the AVM followed by surgical extirpation/destruction. The AVM and overlying skin is widely excised followed by reconstruction.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with severe pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, diplopia, and an orbital bruit in the left eye three weeks after a motor vehicle accident. He also complains of headaches and tinnitus on the left side. The intraocular pressure in the left eye was increased. What is the investigation of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and a bruit is suggestive of traumatic carotid-cavernous fistula. Selective catheter digital subtraction angiography is the investigation of choice.


A carotid cavernous fistula is an arteriovenous fistula communicating between the internal carotid artery and the cavernous sinus.
Causes: 

  • Severe head trauma (most common in males) 
  • Degenerative vessels (atheromatous or syphilitic disease) without discoverable trauma, especially in women

Types: 

  1. Direct fistula: 
    • High-flow shunts in which carotid artery blood passes directly into the cavernous sinus through a defect in the wall of the intracavernous portion of the internal carotid artery 
  2. Indirect fistula 
    • Dural shunt/ low flow shunt in which the arterial blood flows through the meningeal branches of the external or internal carotid arteries indirectly into the cavernous sinus. Clinical manifestations are subtler than in a direct fistula.


Presentation:

It presents within days or weeks following trauma; usually ipsilateral to the fistula but may be bilateral, or even contralateral.

The classical triad of presentation is pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, and bruit. 

  1. Marked epibulbar vascular dilatation - “Corkscrew vessels”
  2. Chemosis
  3. Pulsatile proptosis associated with a bruit and a thrill
  4. Increased IOP 
  5. Anterior segment ischemia, characterized by corneal epithelial edema, aqueous cells, and flare and in severe cases iris atrophy, cataract, and rubeosis iridis.
  6. Ophthalmoplegia (III-VI nerve palsies)
  7. Ophthalmoscopy findings: optic disc swelling, venous dilatation, and intraretinal hemorrhage from venous stasis, and impaired retinal blood flow.
  8. Visual loss
    • Immediate - due to ocular or optic nerve damage
    • Delayed - as a result of exposure keratopathy, secondary glaucoma, central retinal vein occlusion, anterior segment ischemia, or ischaemic optic neuropathy.

Investigations:

  • Selective catheter Digital subtraction angiography is the investigation of choice.
  • CT and MRI angiography can also be done


Treatment: mostly conservative. Embolization during arteriography is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented with complaints of cough with sputum, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. There is a history of repeated lung and sinus infections since childhood. His BMI is 18 kg/m2 and has bilateral nasal polyps. Both lungs have coarse rhonchi and a chest radiograph shows evidence of bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis. To confirm the suspected diagnosis of cystic fibrosis, which of the following is the next best investigation of choice?

choices.text: Isolation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa on repeated sputum cultures

questions.solution:
In a suspected case of cystic fibrosis, a sweat chloride value is the investigation of choice. Values >60 mmol/L are diagnostic. 

The primary clinical manifestations of cystic fibrosis (CF) are due to the effects of the mutated cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and pancreas. This protein is a large transmembrane protein involved in the transport of chloride and other ions. Hence, abnormalities of the CFTR lead to abnormalities of salt and water transport.

In the lungs, abnormal CFTR leads to thick, sticky mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance. The patient will have recurrent respiratory infections with the development of bronchiectasis.

The standard test commonly performed to diagnose CF is the sweat chloride test. Elevated values are pathognomonic of this condition, with a cut-off of >60 mmol/L in adults being diagnostic. Values in the range 30–59 mmol/L fall within the indeterminate range.

A large number of mutations can cause CF, therefore genetic testing can be expensive and is not the first test performed for diagnosis when CF is suspected. A negative sweat chloride test does not exclude the diagnosis. In case of high suspicion of CF and a negative sweat test, alternative diagnostic studies such as measurement of nasal membrane potential difference, semen analysis, or assessment of pancreatic function may be done. All patients diagnosed with cystic fibrosis should undergo CFTR genotyping.

Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF but is not specific for the diagnosis because bronchiectasis from any other cause can lead to P. aeruginosa infection.

Categories of CFTR mutations

Classes of defects in the CFTR gene include:

  • the absence of synthesis (class I)
  • defective protein maturation and premature degradation (class II)
  • disordered gating/regulation, such as diminished adenosine triphosphate (ATP) binding and hydrolysis (class III)
  • defective conductance through the ion channel pore (class IV)
  • a reduced number of CFTR transcripts due to a promoter or splicing abnormality (class V)
  • accelerated turnover from the cell surface (class VI).

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient presented with gradually increasing difficulty in breathing for the past 6 months. She is on methotrexate for rheumatoid arthritis. Interstitial Lung Disease is suspected. What is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
High-resolution CT is the investigation of choice for ILD.  

Interstitial lung disease (ILD) refers to the remodeling of interstitial space, the region between the epithelium and endothelium. The main pathology is fibrosis.

It can be broadly classified into:

  •  ILD of known causes like occupational(coal workers' pneumoconiosis, silicosis), rheumatological(rheumatoid arthritis, diffuse>limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, polymyositis, dermatomyositis, and occasionally SLE and Sjogren syndrome), and treatment-induced.
  • ILD of unknown cause, which is also called idiopathic interstitial pneumonia (IIP). 
IIP is further divided into:
  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF)/ Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP): It is the most common form of idiopathic interstitial pneumonia.
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP)
  • Cryptogenic Organizing pneumonia (COP)
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP)
  • Respiratory bronchiolitis associated ILD (RB-ILD)
  • Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
  • ILD is a restrictive lung disease with low V/Q mismatch where the alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient (a-A O2 gradient) is increased due to a defect in diffusion resulting in hypoxemia.

ILD(pulmonary fibrosis) is the most serious adverse effect of prolonged amiodarone (class iii antiarrhythmic) use. Thus, amiodarone is contraindicated in ILD patients.

 

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text: Which among the following is the investigation of choice in renal cell carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The investigation of choice in renal cell carcinoma is CECT.

MRI is the investigation of choice in renal vein involvement as the renal vein is sub-optimally visualized in CECT.

MRI is superior to CT in differentiating benign from malignant thrombus but offers no advantage in staging the nodal disease.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male patient had a sudden tearing type of chest pain. He is a known hypertensive patient for the past 15 years and has not been on regular treatment. Acute coronary syndrome was ruled and he is hemodynamically stable. Considering aortic dissection, which is the next investigation to be performed?
questions.solution:
CT is the initial investigation for aortic dissection. As it is more widely available and takes a shorter time compared to MRI.

MRI, though highly accurate for acute aortic disease evaluation, is usually confined to cases of severe renal insufficiency or absolute contraindications to iodinated contrast medium.

Ultrasound and aortography are not the investigation of choice for aortic dissection. Aortography used to be the gold standard. It involved the injection of high-flow contrast into the vessel. It has been replaced by noninvasive imaging. Intravascular ultrasound can be performed, but the procedure is expensive and requires experience.

The below image depicts a CT chest indicating Type A aortic dissection from the aortic root. (A) Axial view and (B) sagittal view. Arrows indicate intimal flap.

The Stanford classification of aortic dissection is based on whether the ascending aorta is involved:

  • Type A: affects ascending aorta and arch:
    • Requires urgent surgical management
  • Type B: begins beyond brachiocephalic vessels:
    • Dissection commences distal to the left subclavian artery
    • Medical management with blood pressure control

The DeBakey classification divides dissections into:

  • Type I: involves ascending and descending aorta (= Stanford A)
  • Type II: involves ascending aorta only (= Stanford A)
  • Type III: involves descending aorta only, commencing after the origin of the left subclavian artery (= Stanford B)

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presented with pain abdomen. The resident examines the child and found that vitals were stable and tenderness was present in the left lumbar region. Which is the best investigation of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with abdominal pain and tenderness in the left lumbar region following a road traffic accident is suggestive of blunt renal trauma. The investigation of choice is CECT in a hemodynamically stable patient.

Blunt trauma is the main cause of renal injuries and is generally self-limiting. Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock in combination with microscopic haematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding hemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour.

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most of the penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are:

  • Massive hemorrhage
  • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury)
  • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma

Relative indications are:

  • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction
  • Bowel or pancreatic injuries
  • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess 
  • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys 
  • Renal hypertension

Other options:

Option D: Exploratory laparotomy is recommended in unstable patients and those with penetrating renal injuries.

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Kidney Injury Scale

GRADE  

 INJURY DESCRIPTION
I

Contusion

Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
  Hematoma

Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration
II

Hematoma

Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
  Laceration

 <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
III

Laceration 

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
IV Laceration

Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system
  Vascular

Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage
V Laceration Completely shattered kidney
  Laceration   Avulsion of renal hilum, which devascularizes kidney

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulceration?
questions.solution:
Gastroduodenoscopy is considered the investigation of choice for the evaluation of a patient with suspected peptic ulcer disease.

Gastric peptic ulcers are predominantly located along the lesser curvature near the interface of the body and antrum. The most common site of peptic ulcer is the anterior wall of the proximal duodenum, within a few centimeters of the pyloric valve. 

The image below shows a peptic ulcer with a round to oval and sharply punched-out defect, and a clean mucosal margin.

Complications of peptic ulcers:

  • Bleeding - It is the most common complication of posterior duodenal ulcer.
  • Perforation - It is the most common complication of anterior duodenal ulcer and gastric ulcer.
  • Obstruction.
  • Hour-glass deformity of the stomach - Large long-standing gastric ulcers can lead to fibrosis. Fibrosis if present can cause hourglass constriction of the stomach. Barium meal shows double pouched stomach.
  • Tea-pot deformity (handbag stomach) - It is caused by cicatrization and shortening of the lesser curvature.
  • An ulcer can erode posteriorly into the pancreas and anteriorly into the liver.
  • Malignancy.

Related Pearl: Types Of Gastric Ulcers

This is the classification given in Harrisons 20th ed, Principles of Internal Medicine.

  Type Of Ulcer               Location Acid Production Surgical Management
          Type I            Gastric body             Low Distal Gastrectomy Billroth Type 1
          Type II                 Antrum    Low to Normal Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI
          Type III Within 3cm of the pylorus; Accompanied by duodenal ulcers    Normal or High  Distal Gastrectomy and Vagotomy/PPI  
          Type IV                  Cardia              Low  Pouchet, Csendes Procedure

 

The other classification is Modified Johnson's Classification which is as follows: 

Modified Johnson classification for gastric ulcer

I. Lesser curve, incisura - Normal Acid secretion

II. Body of stomach, incisura + duodenal ulcer (active or healed) - Increased Acid secretion

III. Prepyloric - Increased Acid secretion

IV. High on lesser curve - Normal acid secretion

V. Medication induced (NSAID/ acetylsalicylic acid), anywhere in stomach

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of sudden and continuous pain in the right testicle. The pain radiated to the abdomen and the inguinal area associated with nausea and vomiting. What is the investigation of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a likely of testicular torsion. Doppler ultrasonography is the investigation of choice for this condition.

Testicular torsion is typically seen in adolescence and presents with the sudden onset of testicular pain.

It results from a bilateral anatomic defect that leads to increased mobility of the testes (bell­clapper abnormality). Twisting of the spermatic cord typically cuts off the venous drainage of the testis. But, thick-walled arteries remain patent, producing intense vascular engorgement, followed by hemorrhagic infarction.

The morphologic changes range from intense congestion to widespread hemorrhage to testicular infarction depending on the duration of torsion. In advanced stages, the testis is markedly enlarged and consists entirely of soft, necrotic, hemorrhagic tissue.
